Recall: from last time, we showed that...¶

If we assume that for all x,y∈Rdx,y∈Rd, ∥∇f(x)−∇f(y)∥≤L⋅∥x−y∥‖∇f(x)−∇f(y)‖≤L⋅‖x−y‖, then

f(wt+1)≤f(wt)−α(1−12αL)⋅∥∇f(wt)∥2.f(wt+1)≤f(wt)−α(1−12αL)⋅‖∇f(wt)‖2.

If we choose our step size αα to be small enough that 1≥αL1≥αL, then this simplifies to

f(wt+1)≤f(wt)−α2⋅∥∇f(wt)∥2.f(wt+1)≤f(wt)−α2⋅‖∇f(wt)‖2.

That is, the objective is guaranteed to decrease at each iteration! This matches our intuition for why gradient descent should work.

An aside...why do we need sufficiently small step size?¶

With too large a step size, we can overshoot the optimum!

Consider the following case of f(w)=12w2f(w)=12w2. Here f′(w)=∇f(w)=wf′(w)=∇f(w)=w (and f′′(w)=1f″(w)=1), so it's LL-smooth with L=1L=1. Suppose we're at wt=2wt=2 as shown here:

In [2]:
%matplotlib inline

x = numpy.arange(-2,3,0.01)
y = x**2 / 2
pyplot.plot(x,y, label=r"$f(w) = \frac{1}{2}w^2$");
pyplot.scatter([2.0],[2.0**2/2], c="r", zorder=10)
pyplot.legend()

Here our GD update will be wt+1=wt−αf(wt)=2−α⋅2wt+1=wt−αf(wt)=2−α⋅2. If we step with α=1α=1, we go directly to the optimum at w=0w=0. But! If we step with a larger αα, we overshoot, and for α>2α>2, our loss f(w)f(w) actually increases. This illustrates why having sufficiently small steps is necessary for our proof.

Why is our L-smoothness assumption necessary?¶

We can also use a simple example to illustrate why assuming some sort of smoothness is necessary to show this result. Consider the (dumb) example of f(w)=√|w|f(w)=|w|. It is differentiable everywhere except at w=0w=0.

In [3]:
x = numpy.arange(-3,3,0.01)
y = numpy.sqrt(numpy.abs(x))
w = 2;
prev_w = numpy.array(w)
alpha = 0.5;

for it in range(100):
    w = w - alpha * numpy.sign(w)/(2*numpy.sqrt(numpy.abs(w)))
    prev_w = numpy.append(prev_w,w)

  • Gradients around w=0w=0 changes too fast! For w>0w>0, f(w)=√wf(w)=w with f′(w)=12√wf′(w)=12w, |f′′(w)|=14w3/2|f″(w)|=14w3/2.
  • As w↓0w↓0, |f′′(w)|→∞|f″(w)|→∞ so there is no global upper bound for the second derivative, which means we do not have Lipschitz continuous gradients: ∥∥f′(y)−f′(x)∥∥≤L∥y−x∥‖f′(y)−f′(x)‖≤L‖y−x‖ for all x,yx,y
  • GD diverged once we got close to 00

Questions?¶

Stochastic Gradient Descent¶

Basic idea: in gradient descent, just replace the full gradient (which is a sum) with a single gradient example. Initialize the parameters at some value w0∈Rdw0∈Rd, and decrease the value of the empirical risk iteratively by sampling a random example x(t)x(t) uniformly from the training set and then updating

wt+1=wt−αt⋅∇f(wt;x(t))wt+1=wt−αt⋅∇f(wt;x(t))

where as usual wtwt is the value of the parameter vector at time tt, αtαt is the learning rate or step size, and ∇fi∇fi denotes the gradient of the loss function of the iith training example. Compared with gradient descent and Newton's method, SGD is simple to implement and runs each iteration faster.

A potential objection!¶

This is not necessarily going to be decreasing the loss at every step!

  • Because we're just moving in a direction that will decrease the loss for one particular example: this won't necessarily decrease the total loss!

  • So we can't demonstrate convergence by using a proof like the one we used for gradient descent, where we showed that the loss decreases at every iteration of the algorithm.

  • The fact that SGD doesn't always improve the loss at each iteration motivates the question: does SGD even work? And if so, why does SGD work?

Question: Why might it be fine to get an approximate solution to an optimization problem for training?¶

Question: Why might it be fine to get an approximate solution to an optimization problem for training?¶

Because we don't always have to minimize the training loss exactly, as long as the performance on the test set is good enough. In machine learning, generalization matters more than optimization, sadly (for an optimizer).

Understanding why SGD converges¶

Assumption: ff is LL-smooth, i.e. for any xx and yy ∥∇f(x)−∇f(y)∥≤L∥x−y∥.‖∇f(x)−∇f(y)‖≤L‖x−y‖.

Assumption: loss ff is non-negative. (This is without loss of generality if ff is bounded from below, since we can always add a constant to ff in that case to make it non-negative.)

New Assumption for SGD: the variance of the gradients is bounded. For some constant σ>0σ>0, if xx is drawn uniformly at random from the training set, for any ww Ex[∥∇f(w;x)−∇f(w)∥2]≤σ2,Ex[‖∇f(w;x)−∇f(w)‖2]≤σ2, or equivalently, 1n∑x∈D∥∇f(w;x)−∇f(w)∥2≤σ2,1n∑x∈D‖∇f(w;x)−∇f(w)‖2≤σ2, or also equivalently, Ex[∥∇f(w;x)∥2]≤∥∇f(w)∥2+σ2.Ex[‖∇f(w;x)‖2]≤‖∇f(w)‖2+σ2.

Let's derive the quadratic upper bound again (the "descent" lemma)¶

that is, for all x,yx,y,

f(y)≤f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+L2∥y−x∥2f(y)≤f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+L2‖y−x‖2

To begin, consider the univariate function and its derivative ρ(τ)=f(x+τ(y−x))ρ′(τ)=⟨∇f(x+τ(y−x)),y−x⟩(1)(2)(1)ρ(τ)=f(x+τ(y−x))(2)ρ′(τ)=⟨∇f(x+τ(y−x)),y−x⟩

By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,

ρ(1)−ρ(0)=∫10ρ′(τ)dτρ(1)−ρ(0)=∫01ρ′(τ)dτ

If we substitute back in our definition of ρρ, we get f(y)−f(x)=∫10⟨∇f(x+τ(y−x)),y−x>dτf(y)=f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+∫10⟨∇f(x+τ(y−x))−∇f(x),y−x>dτ(3)(4)(3)f(y)−f(x)=∫01⟨∇f(x+τ(y−x)),y−x>dτ(4)f(y)=f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+∫01⟨∇f(x+τ(y−x))−∇f(x),y−x>dτ where in the last step we rearranged, followed by an add and subtract of ⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩.

We can now simplify this as follows. Keep in mind: we assume that for all x,yx,y, ∥∇f(x)−∇f(y)∥≤L∥x−y∥‖∇f(x)−∇f(y)‖≤L‖x−y‖. f(y)=f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+∫10⟨∇f(x+τ(y−x))−∇f(x),y−x>dτ≤f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+∫10∥∇f(x+τ(y−x))−∇f(x)∥∥y−x∥dτ≤f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+∫10L∥x+τ(y−x)−x∥∥y−x∥dτ=f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+L∥y−x∥2∫10τdτ(5)(6)(7)(8)(5)f(y)=f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+∫01⟨∇f(x+τ(y−x))−∇f(x),y−x>dτ(6)≤f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+∫01‖∇f(x+τ(y−x))−∇f(x)‖‖y−x‖dτ(7)≤f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+∫01L‖x+τ(y−x)−x‖‖y−x‖dτ(8)=f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+L‖y−x‖2∫01τdτ where the first inequality comes from Cauchy-Schwarz inequality a⊤b≤∥a∥∥b∥a⊤b≤‖a‖‖b‖, and the second comes from our LL-Lipschitz continuous gradient assumption. which gives us the "descent" lemma (although, for SGD, we no longer guarantee descent) f(y)≤f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+L2∥y−x∥2.f(y)≤f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+L2‖y−x‖2.

Questions?¶

f(y)≤f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+L2∥y−x∥2.f(y)≤f(x)+⟨∇f(x),y−x⟩+L2‖y−x‖2.

Since it holds for all x,yx,y, we can plug in wtwt for xx and wt+1wt+1 for yy, and plug in the SGD update wt+1=wt−αt∇f(wt;x(t))wt+1=wt−αt∇f(wt;x(t)) we have f(wt+1)≤f(wt)+⟨∇f(wt),wt+1−wt⟩+L2∥wt+1−wt∥2=f(wt)−αt⟨∇f(wt),f(wt;x(t))⟩+α2tL2∥∥∇f(wt;x(t))∥∥2(9)(10)(9)f(wt+1)≤f(wt)+⟨∇f(wt),wt+1−wt⟩+L2‖wt+1−wt‖2(10)=f(wt)−αt⟨∇f(wt),f(wt;x(t))⟩+αt2L2‖∇f(wt;x(t))‖2 But the inner product term can be positive or negative, so we are not guaranteed to decrease the value of ff after each step!

f(wt+1)≤f(wt)−αt⟨∇f(wt),f(wt;x(t))⟩+α2tL2∥∇f(wt;x(t))∥2.f(wt+1)≤f(wt)−αt⟨∇f(wt),f(wt;x(t))⟩+αt2L2‖∇f(wt;x(t))‖2.

Although this isn't a descent method, but this is going to tend to be decaying in expectation. Let's take the expectation of both sides conditioned on wtwt. The randomness here is over the random choice of x(t)x(t).

E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤E[f(wt)−αt⟨∇f(wt),f(wt;x(t))⟩+α2tL2∥∇f(wt;x(t))∥2∣∣∣wt]E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤E[f(wt)−αt⟨∇f(wt),f(wt;x(t))⟩+αt2L2‖∇f(wt;x(t))‖2|wt]

By linearity of expectation and by factoring out constants that don't depend on the random choice of x(t)x(t), E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt⟨E[∇f(wt;x(t))∣wt],∇f(wt)⟩+α2tL2E[∥∇f(wt;x(t))∥2∣∣wt].E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt⟨E[∇f(wt;x(t))∣wt],∇f(wt)⟩+αt2L2E[‖∇f(wt;x(t))‖2|wt].

Pause¶

E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt⟨E[∇f(wt;x(t))∣wt],∇f(wt)⟩+α2tL2E[∥∇f(wt;x(t))∥2∣∣wt]E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt⟨E[∇f(wt;x(t))∣wt],∇f(wt)⟩+αt2L2E[‖∇f(wt;x(t))‖2|wt]

Now, the first conditional expectation is E[∇f(wt;x(t))∣wt]=1n∑x∈D∇f(wt;x)=∇f(wt)E[∇f(wt;x(t))∣wt]=1n∑x∈D∇f(wt;x)=∇f(wt) Althought wtwt depends on the randomness in all previous iterations, because of the conditioning on wtwt, the only randomness here is the selection of the example x(t)x(t), which is uniformly at random from the training set.

So we get E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt⟨∇f(wt),∇f(wt)⟩+α2tL2E[∥∇f(wt;x(t))∥2∣∣wt]=f(wt)−αt∥∇f(wt)∥2+α2tL2E[∥∇f(wt;x(t))∥2∣∣wt](11)(12)(11)E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt⟨∇f(wt),∇f(wt)⟩+αt2L2E[‖∇f(wt;x(t))‖2|wt](12)=f(wt)−αt‖∇f(wt)‖2+αt2L2E[‖∇f(wt;x(t))‖2|wt]

E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt∥∇f(wt)∥2+α2tL2E[∥∇f(wt;x(t))∥2∣∣wt]E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt‖∇f(wt)‖2+αt2L2E[‖∇f(wt;x(t))‖2|wt]

Recall our bounded variance assumption of the stochastic gradients: for all ww,

Ex[∥∇f(w;x)∥2]≤∥∇f(w)∥2+σ2.Ex[‖∇f(w;x)‖2]≤‖∇f(w)‖2+σ2.

Applying this to the second expecation gives us E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt∥∇f(wt)∥2+α2tL2(∥∇f(wt)∥2+σ2).E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt‖∇f(wt)‖2+αt2L2(‖∇f(wt)‖2+σ2).

This simplifies to E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt(1−αtL2)∥∇f(wt)∥2+α2tσ2L2.E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt(1−αtL2)‖∇f(wt)‖2+αt2σ2L2.

Pause¶

E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt(1−αtL2)∥∇f(wt)∥2+α2tσ2L2.E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt(1−αtL2)‖∇f(wt)‖2+αt2σ2L2.

If we constrain the step size to be sufficiently small, αtL≤1αtL≤1, then this can be further simplified to E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt2∥∇f(wt)∥2+α2tσ2L2.E[f(wt+1)∣wt]≤f(wt)−αt2‖∇f(wt)‖2+αt2σ2L2. Let's call this the progress bound of SGD

Finally, let's take the full expected value over all the randomness in the algorithm, not just this conditional expectation. By the law of total expectation, this yields E[f(wt+1)]=E[E[f(wt+1)∣wt]]≤E[f(wt)]−αt2E[∥∇f(wt)∥2]+α2tσ2L2(13)(14)(13)E[f(wt+1)]=E[E[f(wt+1)∣wt]](14)≤E[f(wt)]−αt2E[‖∇f(wt)‖2]+αt2σ2L2

Pause¶

Rearranging the above expression, we can get αt2E[∥∇f(wt)∥2]≤E[f(wt)]−E[f(wt+1)]+α2tσ2L2.αt2E[‖∇f(wt)‖2]≤E[f(wt)]−E[f(wt+1)]+αt2σ2L2.

Now, let's imagine that we run KK total iterations of SGD, and we sum both sides of this expression going from tt from 00 to K−1K−1. This yields K−1∑t=0αt2E[∥∇f(wt)∥2]≤(K−1∑t=0(E[f(wt)]−E[f(wt+1)]))+σ2L2K−1∑t=0α2t.∑t=0K−1αt2E[‖∇f(wt)‖2]≤(∑t=0K−1(E[f(wt)]−E[f(wt+1)]))+σ2L2∑t=0K−1αt2.

K−1∑t=0αt2E[∥∇f(wt)∥2]≤(K−1∑t=0(E[f(wt)]−E[f(wt+1)]))+σ2L2K−1∑t=0α2t.∑t=0K−1αt2E[‖∇f(wt)‖2]≤(∑t=0K−1(E[f(wt)]−E[f(wt+1)]))+σ2L2∑t=0K−1αt2.

Observe that this sum telescopes!

So we get K−1∑t=0(E[f(wt)]−E[f(wt+1)])=E[f(w0)]−E[f(wK)]=f(w0)−E[f(wK)]≤f(w0),(15)(16)(17)(15)∑t=0K−1(E[f(wt)]−E[f(wt+1)])=E[f(w0)]−E[f(wK)](16)=f(w0)−E[f(wK)](17)≤f(w0), where this last inequality follows from our assumption that the loss is non-negative. Thus, K−1∑t=0αt2E[∥∇f(wt)∥2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2K−1∑t=0α2t.∑t=0K−1αt2E[‖∇f(wt)‖2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2∑t=0K−1αt2.

K−1∑t=0αt2E[∥∇f(wt)∥2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2K−1∑t=0α2t.∑t=0K−1αt2E[‖∇f(wt)‖2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2∑t=0K−1αt2.

Now, let ρt=αt∑K−1k=0αt.ρt=αt∑k=0K−1αt.

Multiply by 1=∑K−1k=0αt∑K−1k=0αt1=∑k=0K−1αt∑k=0K−1αt on the LHS, we have (K−1∑t=0αt2)K−1∑t=0ρtE[∥∇f(wt)∥2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2K−1∑t=0α2t.(∑t=0K−1αt2)∑t=0K−1ρtE[‖∇f(wt)‖2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2∑t=0K−1αt2.

(K−1∑t=0αt2)K−1∑t=0ρtE[∥∇f(wt)∥2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2K−1∑t=0α2t.(∑t=0K−1αt2)∑t=0K−1ρtE[‖∇f(wt)‖2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2∑t=0K−1αt2.

But if we let ττ be a random varible with distribution given by ρρ (this is a distribution because it sums to 11), then we can write this left side in expected-value form as (K−1∑t=0αt2)⋅E[∥∇f(wτ)∥2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2K−1∑t=0α2t,(∑t=0K−1αt2)⋅E[‖∇f(wτ)‖2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2∑t=0K−1αt2, where now the expected value is taken over both the algorthmic randomness and the choice of ττ. We can think of wτwτ as the output of SGD run for a random number of steps.

Questions?¶

Constant Step Size¶

Here, we have αt=α≤1/Lαt=α≤1/L

(K−1∑t=0αt2)⋅E[∥∇f(wτ)∥2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2K−1∑t=0α2tαK2⋅E[∥∇f(wτ)∥2]≤f(w0)+α2σ2LK2(18)(19)(18)(∑t=0K−1αt2)⋅E[‖∇f(wτ)‖2]≤f(w0)+σ2L2∑t=0K−1αt2(19)αK2⋅E[‖∇f(wτ)‖2]≤f(w0)+α2σ2LK2

Multiplying both sides by 2αK2αK, E[∥∇f(wτ)∥2]≤2f(w0)αK+ασ2LE[‖∇f(wτ)‖2]≤2f(w0)αK+ασ2L

How should we interpret this?¶

E[∥∇f(wτ)∥2]≤2f(w0)αK+ασ2LE[‖∇f(wτ)‖2]≤2f(w0)αK+ασ2L

SGD with constant step size converges to a "noise ball" (a.k.a. "noise floor")! Gradient magnitude doesn't necessarily go to zero

Even if we run for a very large number of iterations, limK→∞2f(w0)αK+ασ2L=ασ2L≠0.limK→∞2f(w0)αK+ασ2L=ασ2L≠0. For many applications this is fine...but it seems somehow lacking.

How should we interpret this?¶

E[∥∇f(wτ)∥2]≤2f(w0)αK+ασ2LE[‖∇f(wτ)‖2]≤2f(w0)αK+ασ2L

(Figure shamelessly stolen from Mark Schmidt)

Question: how can we make the noise ball smaller?¶

We can make this arbitrarily small¶

E[∥∇f(wτ)∥2]≤2f(w0)αK+ασ2LE[‖∇f(wτ)‖2]≤2f(w0)αK+ασ2L

(Figure shamelessly stolen from Mark Schmidt)

We can make this arbitrarily small¶

By choosing the step size constant as a function of the number of steps KK we plan to run. If we minize the RHS of E[∥∇f(wτ)∥2]≤2f(w0)αK+ασ2LE[‖∇f(wτ)‖2]≤2f(w0)αK+ασ2L with respect to αα, we will get α=min⎛⎝√2f(w0)σ2LK,1L⎞⎠α=min(2f(w0)σ2LK,1L) where the 1/L1/L came from the earlier requirement of αL≤1αL≤1 in order to get to this point (the progress bound).

Substitute this in, E[∥∇f(wτ)∥2]≤2f(w0)Kmax(√σ2LK2f(w0),L)+σ2Lmin⎛⎝√2f(w0)σ2LK,1L⎞⎠E[‖∇f(wτ)‖2]≤2f(w0)Kmax(σ2LK2f(w0),L)+σ2Lmin(2f(w0)σ2LK,1L)

Then since min(x,y)≤xmin(x,y)≤x and max(x,y)≤x+ymax(x,y)≤x+y, E[∥∇f(wτ)∥2]≤2f(w0)K(√σ2LK2f(w0)+L)+σ2L⋅2f(w0)σ2LK=√2f(w0)σ2LK+2Lf(w0)K+√2f(w0)σ2LK=√8f(w0)σ2LK+2Lf(w0)K.E[‖∇f(wτ)‖2]≤2f(w0)K(σ2LK2f(w0)+L)+σ2L⋅2f(w0)σ2LK=2f(w0)σ2LK+2Lf(w0)K+2f(w0)σ2LK=8f(w0)σ2LK+2Lf(w0)K. This is decreasing to zero as K→∞K→∞.

Questions?¶

Under strong convexity, we can do better¶

Recall the progress bound of SGD E[f(wt+1)]≤E[f(wt)]−αt2E[∥∇f(wt)∥2]+α2tσ2L2.E[f(wt+1)]≤E[f(wt)]−αt2E[‖∇f(wt)‖2]+αt2σ2L2.

If ff is μμ-strongly convex, we have that ∥∇f(x)∥2≥2μ(f(x)−f∗)‖∇f(x)‖2≥2μ(f(x)−f∗), and so E[f(wt+1)]≤E[f(wt)]−αt2E[2μ(f(wt)−f∗)]+α2tσ2L2E[f(wt+1)]≤E[f(wt)]−αt2E[2μ(f(wt)−f∗)]+αt2σ2L2

E[f(wt+1)]≤E[f(wt)]−αt2E[2μ(f(wt)−f∗)]+α2tσ2L2E[f(wt+1)]≤E[f(wt)]−αt2E[2μ(f(wt)−f∗)]+αt2σ2L2

Subtracting the global minimum f∗f∗ from both sides, E[f(wt+1)−f∗]≤E[f(wt)−f∗]−αtμE[f(wt)−f∗]+α2tσ2L2,E[f(wt+1)−f∗]≤E[f(wt)−f∗]−αtμE[f(wt)−f∗]+αt2σ2L2, which simplifies to E[f(wt+1)−f∗]≤(1−αtμ)E[f(wt)−f∗]+α2tσ2L2.E[f(wt+1)−f∗]≤(1−αtμ)E[f(wt)−f∗]+αt2σ2L2.

Again supposing a constant step size, E[f(wt+1)−f∗]≤(1−αμ)⋅E[f(wt)−f∗]+α2σ2L2.E[f(wt+1)−f∗]≤(1−αμ)⋅E[f(wt)−f∗]+α2σ2L2.

Subtracting ασ2L2μασ2L2μ from both sides, E[f(wt+1)−f∗−ασ2L2μ]≤(1−αμ)⋅E[f(wt)−f∗]+α2σ2L2−ασ2L2μ≤(1−αμ)⋅E[f(wt)−f∗−ασ2L2μ].E[f(wt+1)−f∗−ασ2L2μ]≤(1−αμ)⋅E[f(wt)−f∗]+α2σ2L2−ασ2L2μ≤(1−αμ)⋅E[f(wt)−f∗−ασ2L2μ].

E[f(wt+1)−f∗−ασ2L2μ]≤(1−αμ)⋅E[f(wt)−f∗−ασ2L2μ].E[f(wt+1)−f∗−ασ2L2μ]≤(1−αμ)⋅E[f(wt)−f∗−ασ2L2μ].

We can now apply this recursively! Over KK total iterations, E[f(wK)−f∗−ασ2L2μ]≤(1−αμ)K⋅(f(w0)−f∗−ασ2L2μ)≤exp(−αμK)⋅(f(w0)−f∗)(20)(21)(20)E[f(wK)−f∗−ασ2L2μ]≤(1−αμ)K⋅(f(w0)−f∗−ασ2L2μ)(21)≤exp⁡(−αμK)⋅(f(w0)−f∗) where we were able to drop the expected value on the right because w0w0 is not a random variable.

Note that we again used the inequality (1−x)≤exp(−x)(1−x)≤exp⁡(−x) for all xx,

from labellines import labelLine, labelLines

This yields a final bound of E[f(wK)−f∗]≤exp(−αμK)⋅(f(w0)−f∗)+ασ2L2μE[f(wK)−f∗]≤exp⁡(−αμK)⋅(f(w0)−f∗)+ασ2L2μ

E[f(wK)−f∗]≤exp(−αμK)⋅(f(w0)−f∗)+ασ2L2μE[f(wK)−f∗]≤exp⁡(−αμK)⋅(f(w0)−f∗)+ασ2L2μ

Again we have the same issue of convergence to a noise ball for constant αα. We can minimize this over αα to pick a number-of-steps-dependent step size. 0=−μKexp(−αμK)⋅(f(w0)−f∗)+σ2L2μ→α=1μKlog(2μ2(f(w0)−f∗)Kσ2L).0=−μKexp⁡(−αμK)⋅(f(w0)−f∗)+σ2L2μ→α=1μKlog⁡(2μ2(f(w0)−f∗)Kσ2L).

This yields E[f(wK)−f∗]≤σ2L2μ2(f(w0)−f∗)K⋅(f(w0)−f∗)+σ2L2μ⋅1μKlog(2μ2(f(w0)−f∗)Kσ2L)=σ2L2μ2K+σ2L2μ2Klog(2μ2(f(w0)−f∗)Kσ2L)=σ2L2μ2Klog(2eμ2(f(w0)−f∗)Kσ2L).E[f(wK)−f∗]≤σ2L2μ2(f(w0)−f∗)K⋅(f(w0)−f∗)+σ2L2μ⋅1μKlog⁡(2μ2(f(w0)−f∗)Kσ2L)=σ2L2μ2K+σ2L2μ2Klog⁡(2μ2(f(w0)−f∗)Kσ2L)=σ2L2μ2Klog⁡(2eμ2(f(w0)−f∗)Kσ2L). This is indeed approaching 00 as KK becomes large!
